thread.title_full: Troubles inquiry into British soldiers is 'unfair', minister says as he calls for 'inappropriate' system to be overhauled

author: Ben Farmer
title: Troubles inquiry into British soldiers is 'unfair', minister says as he calls for 'inappropriate' system to be overhauled
text:
C riminal inquiries into British soldiers' conduct during the Troubles are "not appropriate" and must be overhauled to ensure troops are not "unfairly treated or disproportionately investigated", ministers said on Thursday night.
James Brokenshire, Northern Ireland Secretary, said that investigations were now focused too heavily on finding abuses by security forces, even though terrorists were responsible for 90 per cent of deaths.
The current approach was “not sustainable”, he said, as he called for a new system which ensured "terrorists are not treated more favourably than former soldiers and police officers".
Speaking to MPs, Mr Brokenshire said that investigations should also be time limited to five years so they do not become open ended.
His comments come amid growing concern in the military that veterans in their 60s and 70s face years of investigation over alleged crimes after police reopened inquiries into hundreds of killings.
A British armoured car moves through Strabane, Co Tyrone, Tuesday April 29, 1969 Credit: PA I t emerged late last year that as many as 1,000 soldiers are under investigation over 302 killings that took place over a 35-year period since 1969.
The government has already pledged to shut down the inquiry into alleged abuses by troops in Iraq after admitting it had become a "witch hunt". 
Speaking about the Northern Ireland probes, Mr Brokenshire said: "We will never accept any kind of spurious moral equivalence between those who sought to uphold the rule of law and the terrorists who sought to destroy it.
Northern Ireland Secretary James Brokenshire Credit: Eddie Mulholland "For us, politically motivated violence in Northern Ireland was never justified, whether it was carried out by republicans or loyalists.
"We will continue to reject attempts to place the state at the heart of every atrocity or somehow to displace responsibility away from those who carried out terrorist attacks, namely the terrorists themselves."
M r Brokenshire’s comments come after he last month wrote in The Sunday Telegraph that the current system is not working.
He went on: “I recognise concerns that the current mechanisms focus disproportionately on cases involving, or allegedly involving, the state.
“As a result leaving many victims of terrorism feeling ignored.”
Mr Brokenshire's colleague, Northern Ireland minister Kris Hopkins, also said the system was in need of reform.
He said: "The present system is not appropriate. It is disproportionate and we need a new system which was agreed under the Stormont Agreement."
Ihat will be wound up after Phil Shiner, the human rights lawyer who brought most of the Iraq cases, was earlier this month struck off after being found guilty of recklessness, dishonesty and lack of integrity.
Mr Brokenshire said it was “appalling when people try to make a business of dragging our brave troops through the courts”.
Mr Brokenshire said the current investigations in Northern Ireland “are simply not delivering for anyone, including victims and survivors on all sides who suffered most during the Troubles”.
A new Historical Investigations Unit to replace current inquiries run by Northern Ireland police will be legally obliged to be “fair, balanced and crucially proportionate”, he said.
The unit would have to look at terrorist attacks on troops, such as the 1979 Warrenpoint ambush which killed 18 soldiers, he said.
He said: “We are looking at ways of ensuring that where prosecutions do take place terrorists are not treated more favourably than former soldiers and police officers.
“And the bodies will be time limited to five years, ensuring that this process will not be open ended thereby helping Northern Ireland to move forward.”
Mr Brokenshire also said the new system would consider giving legal support to witnesses called to testify in cases involving their comrades - something which currently does not happen.
Jim Shannon MP, broke down in tears as he recalled his cousin, who had been killed by the IRA.
The Strangford MP who served in the Ulster Defence Regiment (UDR) during the Troubles, said: “I understand very well the concept of closure and wanting justice.
"I want justice for my cousin Kenneth Smith, who was murdered by the IRA."
"I want justice for the four UDR men that the honourable member refers to, a few of whom I knew personally.
"And yet there's no multimillion pound investigation available for that.
"So I resent the idea that this seems to once more represent that one life is worth more than another. "It's not, never will be."
